review.title: Fuzzy Logic in Narrow Sense with Hedges
review.abstract: Classical logic has a serious limitation in that it cannot cope with the issues of vagueness and uncertainty into which fall most modes of human reasoning. In order to provide a foundation for human knowledge representation and reasoning in the presence of vagueness, imprecision, and uncertainty, fuzzy logic should have the ability to deal with linguistic hedges, which play a very important role in the modification of fuzzy predicates. In this paper, we extend fuzzy logic in narrow sense with graded syntax, introduced by Novak et al., with many hedge connectives. In one case, each hedge does not have any dual one. In the other case, each hedge can have its own dual one. The resulting logics are shown to also have the Pavelka-style completeness

sections.text: Classical logic has a serious limitation insofar as it cannot cope with the problems of uncertainty and uncertainty in which most forms of human thought fall. In order to provide a basis for the presentation and argumentation of human knowledge in the presence of vagueness, imprecision and uncertainty, blurred logic should be able to deal with linguistic hedges, which play a very important role in modifying blurred predicates. In this essay, we extend the blurred logic in the strict sense with the graduated syntax introduced by Nova'k et al. with many hedge connections. In one case, each hedge does not have a dual one, in the other case, each hedge may have its own dual one. The resulting logic also exhibits completeness in Pavelka style.KEYWORDSFuzzy Logic in Narrow Sense, Hedge Connective, First-Order Logic, Pavelka-Style Completeness.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: The extension of logical systems of mathematical fuzzy logic (MFL) with hedges is axiomatized by Ha ́ jek [1], Vychodil [2], Esteva et al. [3], among others. Hedges are called turkey stressing or truth-depressing when they, respectively, strengthen or weaken the meaning of the proposal applied. Intuitively, on a chain of truth values, the truth function of a truth-depressing (or truth-emphasizing) hedge (mandatory) is given a superdiagonal (resp., subdiagonal) non-decreasing function 0 and 1.

sections.heading: 3. Fuzzy Logic in Narrow Sense with Hedges
sections.text: In order to provide a basis for a computational approach to human thinking in the presence of vagueness, inaccuracy and uncertainty, fuzzy logic should be able to deal with linguistic hedges, which play a very important role in modifying fuzzy predicates. In this section, therefore, we will expand FLn to include hedge connectors to model human knowledge and thinking. In addition to expanding language and the definition of formulas, new logical axioms are added to characterize the properties of the new connectors. sections.heading: 3.2. FLn with many dual hedges
sections.text: It can be observed that each hedge can have a dual one, e.g. light and rather than a dual hedge of very and very high. Therefore, there may be axioms expressing dual relationships of hedges in addition to axioms expressing their comparative truth modification strength. In this subsection, FLn is extended by many dual hedges in which each hedge has its own dual uniformity. sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we extend fuzzy logic in the narrower sense by many hedge combinations to provide a basis for the presentation and argumentation of human knowledge. In fuzzy logic in the narrower sense, both syntax and semantics are gradually evaluated in [0,1]. The graduated approach to syntax can be seen as an elegant and natural generalization of classical logic for inferences under vagueness, since it allows to explicitly present and argue with partial truths, i.e. to prove partially true conclusions from partially true premises, and enjoys the Pavelka-like completeness. FLn is extended in two cases: (i) Each hedge has no dual, and (ii) each hedge can have its own dual. In addition to expanding the language and definition of formulas, new logical axioms are added that characterize the properties of hedge combinations.
